üßµSecuring our freedom from those who would rule us for their benefit requires us to recognize and reject the seductive fairytale of bigger more benevolent government.

Reducing the size of this broken government is the only way to regain prosperity and virtue in our society.

üßµInside of government and in the elections that shape government they see a contest for raw power. If they can win it, they can rule you. The bigger the government, the bigger the prize should they claim it. And ultimately the prize is that you work for them.

üßµEven those advocating for a bigger more intrusive government as a means for achieving more prosperity and virtue in society do not believe the fairytale. They will recite the fairytale for others but what they want for themselves is power.

üßµKnowing that government is severely broken, and being dissatisfied with the people chosen and the process followed by these people once elected, why do some still advocate for a bigger more intrusive government as a means for achieving more prosperity and virtue in society?

üßµsummarizing:

(1) The public knows voters have failed to pick exceptional legislators.

(2) The public sees the process which would allow unexceptional people to make adequate decisions does not exist in Congress.

üßµWhether you choose to blame campaign finance, election rules, corruption, special interests, congressional leadership, disregard for congressional rules of order, or a host of other things, you know the process inside the legislature is horribly broken.

üßµ But any person paying any attention can see Congress does not follow an orderly process that would allow regular, or even exceptional, people to converge on good or even adequate solutions for the small things or for the big things.

üßµ As for the second proposition:
Can regular people be assembled and conduct themselves in regular order so as to make better decisions than any of them could make alone? I want to believe this is possible, not for regulating everything, but to settle the few necessary laws.

üßµ As for the first proposition:
Serving in Congress, I assure you that you and your neighbors have not selected someone more virtuous or intelligent than you or your neighbors to make the rules for you and your neighbors. Even you and your neighbors mostly agree upon this point.

üßµ (2) a regular person, possessing all inadequacies of regular people, once elevated to a far-away lawmaking body following a regular order will he himself make better decisions for regular people than regular people could make for themselves, or than he could make for himself.

üßµThe fallacy that bigger government provides us a more virtuous society is found in one of two propositions:

(1) people to be governed will reliably select lawmakers more intelligent and virtuous than the average one of them to make rules regulating the behavior of all of them.

üßµGood governments are those which institute laws that only criminalize behavior of criminals.

A good government would not make laws that regulate most aspects of every person‚Äôs life.

Yet some pretend a more prosperous and virtuous society can result from bigger government.

My priority is taking care of people, and making sure we are holding the Pentagon accountable when it comes to how we spend billions of dollars every year. These NDAA amendments would allow us to do that.

We need to take care of our lowest paid service members & DOD civilian employees. There's no reason anyone, including our service members & their families, should be relying on food pantry lines or wondering how they are going to afford basic & necessary costs like child care.
In addition, we need transparency about recruitment practices at our public schools, especially in underserved communities of color where opportunities may seem limited and unavailable.

The American people  deserve transparency about how the Pentagon uses its funding -  which exceeds our spending on domestic priorities like education, health, and housing combined. We also need a public disclosure to identify our overseas military footprint.
Former Ambassador to Syria Robert Ford has been raising these issues for years and I‚Äôm grateful for his advocacy.

I was proud to introduce this Syria amendment for the first time in last year‚Äôs NDAA and to be joined by Congressional leaders on war powers. The majority of our caucus agrees on this common-sense amendment, in addition to several colleagues on the other side of the aisle.

The American people deserve public discourse before we engage in conflict overseas that requires the full service & sacrifice of our military personnel. Congressional war powers must be restored. Our U.S. military presence in Syria necessitates a long overdue vote in Congress.
